CORE.name: Accretion Disk
CORE.definition: A structure formed by material orbiting a central body, typically a star or black hole, spiraling inward due to friction and angular momentum transfer.

GROUNDING.evidence_summary: Accretion disks are observed across various wavelengths, from radio waves to X-rays. Their spectral signatures reveal the composition and temperature of the gas. Theoretical models, validated by observations, explain the disk's formation and evolution.

requires: Sufficient supply of gas and dust

relational: Gravity: Central object gravitationally attracts disk material.
Friction: Friction between particles causes heating and inward spiraling.
Angular Momentum Transport: Angular momentum is transferred outwards, allowing material to accrete inwards.

lifecycle: Formation: Material collapses towards central object.
Accretion: Material spirals inward, releasing energy.
Evolution: Disk thins and cools over time.
Dissipation: Material is either accreted or ejected, disk eventually dissipates.
